<description type="note">Title: A mumming for the goldsmiths of London.

46. A MUMMING FOR THE GOLDSMITHS OF LONDON.

[MS. Trin. Coll. Camb., R. 3. 20, pp. 175â178.] And nowe filoweÃ¾e a lettre made in wyse of balade by Ledegate Daun Iohan, of a mommynge, whiche Ã¾e goldesmythes of Ã¾e Cite of London mommed in right fresshe and costele welych desguysing to Ã¾eyre Mayre Eestfeld, vpon Candelmasse day at nyght, affter souper; brought and presented vn to Ã¾e Mayre by an heraude, cleped Fortune. 1 Ãat worÃ¾y Dauid, which Ã¾at sloughe Golye, Ãe first kyng Ã¾at sprang oute of Iesse, Of God echosen, Ã¾e bookes specefye, By Samuel sette in his royal see, With twelve trybus is comen to Ã¾is citee, Brought royal gyfftes, kyngly him taquyte, Ãe noble Mayre to seen and to vysyte. 2 Ãe first trybe, Ã¾e Byble cane well telle, Is called Iuda, Ã¾e hardy, strong lyoun. Fro whos kynredeâfor hit did excelleâ Cryst lyneally he came adowne, Which lyche David was Ã¾e chaumpyoun Ãat sloughe Ã¾e tyraunt, to gete him-self a prysse, Man to restore ageyne to Paradys. 3 Ãis noble Dauid, moost mighty and moost goode, Is nowe descended in his estate royal With alle Ã¾e trybus of Iacobus blood, For to presenten in especial Gyfftes Ã¾at beon boÃ¾e hevenly and moral, Apperteyning vn-to good gouuernaunce, Vn-to Ã¾e Mayre for to doo plesaunce. 4 Frome his cytee of Iherusalem He is come dovne of humble wille and thought; Ãe arke of God, bright as Ã¾e sonne beeme, In-to Ã¾is tovne he haÃ¾e goodely brought, Which designeÃ¾e, if hit be wel sought, Grace and good eure and long prosperitee Perpetuelly to byde in Ã¾is cytee. 5 O yee Levytes, whych bere Ã¾is lordes arke, DooÃ¾e youre devoyre with hevenly armonye Ãe gret mysterye deuoutely for to marke, With laude and prys Ã¾e Lord to magnefye; Of oon acorde sheweÃ¾e your melodye, SyngeÃ¾e for ioye, Ã¾at Ã¾e arke is sent Nowe to Ã¾e Mayre with hoole and truwe entent. 6 Palladyone was a relyk and an ymage sent by Ã¾e goddes into Ã¾e cytee of Troye Ã¾e which kept hem in longe prosperite ageynst alle hir enemys.Whylome Ã¾is arke, abyding in Ã¾e hous Of Ebdomadon, brought in ful gret ioye; For in effect it was more gracyous Ãanne euer was Palladyone of Troye. Hit did gret gladnesse and hit did accoye Thinges contrarye and al aduersytee. Ãeffect Ã¾er-of, whane Dauid did see, 7 And fully knewe, howe God list for to blesse Thorughe his vertu and his mighty grace, Ãat of gladdnesse Ã¾ey might nothing mysseâ Wher hit aboode any maner spaace, God of His might halowed so Ã¾e placeâ Wherfore Kyng Dauid, by gret deuocion, Maade of Ã¾is ark a feyre translacion 8 In-to his hous and his palays royal, Brought by Ã¾e Levytes with gret solempnytee; And he him-self in especyal Daunsed and sang of gret humylyte, And ful deuoutely lefft his ryaltee, With Ephod gyrt, lyche preestis of Ã¾e lawe, To gyf ensaumple howe pryde shoulde be withdrawe 9 In yche estate, who list Ã¾e trouth serche, And to exclude al veyne ambycyoun, Specyally fro mynistres of Ã¾e Chirche, To whome hit longeÃ¾e by deuocyoun, To serve God with hool deffeccyoun And afforne him mynistre in clennesse, Bensaumple of Dauid for al his worÃ¾ynesse. 10 Surge domine in requiem. tuam. Tu est archa sanctificacionis tue.Nowe ryse vp, Lord, in-to Ãy resting place, Aark of Ãyne hooly halowed mansyoun, Ãou aark of wisdome, of vertu and of grace, Keepe and defende in Ã¾y proteccion Ãe Meyre, Ã¾e citeseyns, Ã¾e comunes of Ã¾is tovne, Called in cronycles whylome Nuwe Troye, Graunte hem plente, vertu, honnour and ioye. 11 And for Ã¾at meeknesse is a vertu feyre, WorÃ¾y Dauid, with kyngly excellence, In goodely wyse haÃ¾e made his repayre, O noble Mayre, vn-to youre presence, And to youre hyeghnesse with freondly dilygence Ãis presande brought, oonly for Ã¾e best, Perpetuelly Ã¾is tovne to sette at rest, 12 Of purpoos put Ã¾is aark to youre depoos, With good entent, to make youre hert light; And Ã¾oo three thinges, which Ã¾er inne beo cloos, Shal gif to yowe konnyng, grace and might, For to gouuerne with wisdome, pees and right Ãis noble cytee, and lawes suche ordeyne, Ãat no man shal haue cause for to compleyne. 13 A wrytt with-inn shal vn-to you declare And in effect pleynly specefye, Where yee shal punysshe and where as yee shal spare, And howe Ã¾at Mercy shal Rygour modefye. And youre estate al-so to magnefye, Ãis aark of God, to make you gracyous, Shal stille abyde with you in youre hous. 14 For whyles it bydeÃ¾e stille in youre presence, Ãe hyeghe Lord shal blesse booÃ¾e yowe and youres, Of grace, of fortune sende yowe influence And of vertue alle Ã¾e fresshe floures; And of aduersytee voyde awey Ã¾e shoures, Sette pees and rest, welfare and vnytee Duryng youre tyme thoroughe-oute Ã¾is cytee.
